document.text: Work began this week on nine additional holes for the Falling River Country Club golf course, according to FRCC President Charles T. Moses, Jr. Moses says the back nine holes should be completed sometime in 1984, and will be ready for play by 1965. This addition to the 125-acre course wifi give Appomattox County an 18-hole course, complete with a watering system to keep the .greens in good shape even during hat, dry weather. The greens have been designed to be very picturesque, Moses said this week. Some of them have been set hack in the woods, and the 18th hole, which is in front of the club house, wifi be terraced all around, so that people can sit around the hole and watch the ends of tournaments. The golf-course improvement, which Will cost approximately 90,000, will enable more people to play at once, says Moses. At present, with nine holes, we can accomodate 75 people at one tim e, for example, in a tournament he says. With 18 holes, we will be able to accomodate 150 people. This will give us a complete facility, Moses continues. We will have an 18-hole golf course, a swimming pool, a dub house facility,

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox. document.text: William Alexander  Moses, re tired Civil Engineer, died Friday ev ness  He was bom in Appomattox County, October, 17, 1868 son of dhe lata Charles Thomas arid Mary tVoodsdn Moses. When a young mar. he was in the meritantile bustness. He first clerked in. the store of J.R. Atwood and in 1800 went in busi ness for himself. He served as a Justice of the Peace for Appomat tox County. After successfully tak ing a correspondence course from thè University of Virginia, he be came a certified surveyor in Appo mattox County in 1906, which pro fession he f afri owed until he retir ed .in 1954. document.text: were carefully copied from the originals, under the personal super vision of the Manager, Mr. E. M. Farley, and checked by Mr. J. Paul Hudson, Museum Specialist, Na tional Park Service. Funds fot making the four pieces were provided by the Common wealth of Virginia from a special appropriation of 5000, sponsored by State Senator Charles T. Moses, Appomattox, Virginia, and approv ed by Governor John S. Battle, in 1950, for furnishing the Surrender Room at the McLean House. H. A. Gurney, Monument Super intendent, commenting on the new acquisitions stated that each of the four pieces has an interesting his tory aside from its connection with the Lee and Grant meeting. The two generals had barely left the McLean House on the after noon of Palm Sunday, April 9, 1865, when Federal Officers des cended on Wilmer McLean intent on securing a souvenir from the sur render room. General Phil Sheridan paid Mr. McLean 20 in gold for the small pine table and gave it to General Custer to present to his wife with Sheridans compliments. There are several contemporary eye-witness accounts of the youthful Custer,

document.text: To the Voter, of Appomattox, Charlotte Buckingham and Cumber land Counties My Campaign for the Senate is drawing to a close. The Primary is next Tuesday. I am sorry it wag im possible to see and talk to every voter due tQ thd large number in the District. I earnestly solicit your vote and support. I am deeply grateful to everyone, for the kindness and consideration shown me. I pledge t 0 the Voters of this District, if I am nominated and elected, I will impartially and act ively at all times exert my very best effort for the interest of my District and Welfare of 1 th e State at large. Your friend, CHARLES T. MOSES.

R. Reed, officiated. Proceeding the ceremony, Walter Dresser, cousin of the bride, render ed several selections. Airs. F. B. Cale rendered severalvocal num bers, accompanied at the piano by M iss Cornelia Gills. The bride, who was given in mar riage by her father, wore an ivory satin gown fashioned wit i a sweet heart neckline, long pointed sleeves, elosdy fitted bodice, and a full skirt flaring into a round tvain. Her riigcr tip v.il of tulle fell from a beeri-shaped coronet. The brides only ornament was a Sun burst necklace, an heirloom from the maternal side of her family. She carried a prayer book which was printed in 1838 and belonged to her great-great grand mother on the paternal side of her family.The prayer book was showered with white orchids and iliac.

document.text: The Virginia War Fund,hc.,spon sored by Governor Colgate W. Dar den, Jr, and headed by Homer L. Ferguson, of Newport News, has a quota of 1,835,000 to raise in Vir ginia this fall.This turn is Virginias share in the budgets of the seven teen agencies united in the Nation al War Fund. These include USO and other war front agencies, relief groups serving the civilian popula tions of our Allies and others de signed to relieve distress of refu gees from or populations in occu pied countries. Through one appeal to be conducted tills autumn, the Fund hopes to raise this sum. Garland Gray is chairman of the Fund for the Fourth District, and Charles T. Moses is chairman for Appomattox County. In this county a commendable start has already been made to ward raising a county quota of 3,600.00. A meeting was held here last Thursday night at the court house, and another at Pamplin on Tuesday night ef this week. W. M. Abbitt is treasurer of the War Fund drive for this county, and Miss Marguerite Gilliam is sec- tetary. Contributions may be mail ed to either of them, or to Mr. Moses.

document.text: The new fire house and com munity building at Gladstone was dedicated officially on Sat urday in ceremonies which in cluded addresses by Lt. Gover nor Mills Godwin and Congress man John O. Marsh, of the 7th District. Godwin, commending Glad stone residents for their woric, said It is the spirit of Virgin ians to be self - sustaining and not to ask the federal govern ment for help. Throughout tirrgj, the nation has had to have great people in order to accomplish great things and remain free. These can be accomplished through cooperative community efforts such as the erection of this fire station. Congressman John O. Marsh, the other speaker at the dedica tion, also warned of the increas ing role the federal government plays in the affairs of the people. Godwin commented that on ills travels through Virginia it gave him a feeling of pride to see how Virginians take care of their own needs without the aid of the fed eral government. There is a need of awakening in the people of the great ned of public spiritedness such as ouir forefathers had. We have been endowed with these privileges which we enjoy upon a great deal of sacrifice on their part, and we must do our part to keep these privileges. Godwin was Introduced by State Sen. Charles T. Moses, of Appomattox. Other Celebrities and Officers Lina Trent, of Appomattox, performed a baton twirling rou tine and Sandra Eustler, a dance during the festivities. Fran Rue- sell, of Lynchburg, was master of ceremonies. Jiarry M. Dixon, president of ie Gtaftdnw Volunteer Wee De- w-V partment, reported that the fire  department began operation on April 5, 1963. Twenty - three firemen are on call, nine of whom have attended special fire fighting schools and received certificates in firefighting. Total debt remaining on the building and fire truck is 8,000, Dixon said. Dixon introduced the officers and directors of the department, a non - stock corporation, as follows H. M. Dixon, president W. F. Quinn, vice president L. E. Moore, chief Agnes C. Hers- ley, secretary M. B. Miller, treasurer F. J. Justus, director Nelson County H. H. Hlggen- botham, dirccotor Amherst Coun ty J. H. Dixon, director Buck ingham County and James Phelps, director Appomattox County. document.text: The cry of gerrymander was readied for use here today, as lo cal political eyes were popped all most out of their sockets by a tom tative plan for reapportionment of the membership of the . Virginia General Assembly was put forwarl by the Legislative Kedistrictinz Commission. The proposal, as ss nounced in Richmond would not om ly tear Appomattox from its politf cal moorings, but would virtual put a political blitzkreig on bosh State Senator Charles T. Moses and Delegate John B. Boatwright. The State Constitution requires a apportionment of membership in the General Assembly after, -the federal census each ten years with membership on a population basis. A Legislative Commission was ap pointed to work oqt  redistricting proposal. It is the proposal which has been hatched by this commis sion that is causing the headaches on local Political fronts.

document.text: The Appomattox Lions Club at its March 31 meeting featured two county winners in the Flue-cured Tobacco Production Contest.  Mr. Thomas Hall, general manager of the Virginia Dark-Fired Tobacco Growers Marketing. Association, made the awards. First prize for be ing first in the State of Virginia went to Harold Martin, of Appomat tox. The prize was a one hundred dollar Savings Bond. Wayne Moore, Gladstone, was awarded a cash prize of ten dollars as the eighth place winner in the state contest. Mr. Charles T. Moses, State Sena tor from Appomattox, was present to introduce Mr. Hall and the two winners to the Lions Club members. Senator Moses compared the por tion of the fire-cured tobacco pro ducers in 1931 when the Virginia Dark-Fired Tobacco Growers Market ing Association was organised, - and that of the growers today. Ha then introduced Mr. Martin and Wayne Moore, the winners, and Mr. Hall, who made the awards. Mr. Hall then told a little mort of the history of the Growers As sociation and explained the contest which they are sponsoring. The pur pose of this contest is to encourage young fanners to adopt production and marketing practices that will re sult in higher yields of better qual ity tobacco. The participants F. F. A., 4-H, or N. F. A. students, keep detailed records of the improved practices, such as having soil tested, insect control, and others, and turn this record in when the crop is mar keted. The two winners, Harold Martin, first, and Wayne Moore, eighth, hon ored at this meeting, are both F. F. A. students at the Appomattox High School, Appomattox, Va.

document.text: The annual banquet of the Appo mattox County Teachers Association was held Monday, Feb. 7, in the Ap pomattox school cafeteria. , Mr. Francis Irving, president of the Association, presided. He first introduced Superintendent J. A. Burke, who in turn introduced Dr. Robert F. Williams, executive secre tary of the Virginia Education As sociation. Dr. Williams was the prin cipal speaker. He was accompanied by Mrs. Williams. In his introduction, Mr. Burke sketched the career of Dr. Williams, first as a high school teacher, then principal, superintendent, and then head of the Elementary Department in the state. He characterized Dr. Williams as a fighter for the under dog. Dr. Williams began his speech after a reference .to his long friend ship with Mr. Burke, with a warm tribute to State Senator Charles T. Moses, of Appomattox. He said, No one has fought more consistently for education in Virginia than Sena tor Moses. The rest of his address was devot ed to a study of retirement bene fits, disability allowances and sick leave, under Virginia state law. Dr. Williams noted that there are now 700,000 children in school in Virginia and 1,300 more teachers are employed than last year .through out the state. The rising birthrate means that still more teachers will be needed. The banquet was served by Mrs. L. L. Stanley and the cafeteria staff. Members of the seventh grade, un der the direction of Miss Flora Belle Williams, decorated the tables and made fate favors.

document.text: The American Legion Auxili ary held its 43rd Annual Con vention at Virginia Beach, on Sept. 7, 8, and 9. Attending this convention from Appomattox Unit 104 was Mrs. Charles T. Moses, Jr. and Mrs. Shearer B. Robert son. At this meeting it was an nounced that Appomattox Unit 104 won first prize in their Poppy Window for the Dept, of Virginia. Mrs. Robertson accepted the check for this award in the ab sence of the Poppy Chairman. Mrs. John S. Moore and Mrs. E. T. Bruce were honored by hav ing membership given them in The Liberty Bell Ringers. Ap pomattox Unit 104 was also first in membership in the 4th. dis trict and brought home a pair of boxing gloves to present to the unit as being the champs of the district. The Appomattox Unit 104 is honored to have one of our mem bers, Mrs. C. T. Moses, Jr. as first vice president of the 2nd and 4th District Dept, of Virgin ia. Mrs. Moses was installed in this office at the convention at Virginia Beach. The Appomattox Unit 104 held their monthly meeting on Sept. 17th at the Post Home. At this time the following officers were installed for the 1962-63 sessions, president, Mrs. Shearer B. Moses Jr. The Unit has already piaced the American Flag in each room I of the Appomattox High School, I Spout Spring arid Evergreen schools. Plans are in progress I now to place them in Pamplin, B ! Oakville and Vera Schools. This I is part of their Americanism pro-  gram. The Auxiliary also voted B to sponsor the Brownie Troops B in Appomattox for the coming B year. The next monthly meeting of the auxiliary will be held on October 8th in the home of Mrs.  c . T. Moses, Jr. Mrs. Mary Grey 1 will have charge of the program.

document.text: State Senator Charles T. Moses of Appomattox, representing the 11th District Dr. William A, Pennington of Buckingham, Dele gate from Buckingham. Appo mattox and Cumberland coun ties, plan to run again for their respective offices, according to latest reports. Senator Moses, president pro tern of the Virginia Senate, and a senator since 1936, represents the 11th district which includes Appcmattox, Buckingham, Cum berland, Powhatan, Amherst, Nel son, and Amelia counties. He said on Monday that he will definitely run again, and that lie appreciates past and pre sent support from the people of the 11th district. Dr. Pennington, in a published interview, said I expect to run. I dont know what will happen but so far I dont have any op position. Pennington has serv ed in two sessions of the General Assembly. He said he also pro bably would make his formal an-  nouncement at his district Demo-  era tic Committee meeting, the date for which has not been set. Ash Trays To Valentines Save Them, Says Club

document.text: State Senator Charles T. Moses, as a member- of the resolutions com mittee, secured passage by the an nual convention of the Young Dem ocratic Clubs of Virginia ir. Roan oke last Friday and Saturday, of a timely resolution recommending that the State Board of Education end the Budget Commission seek State appropriations to help defray the cost of school transportation. document.text: State Sehator Charles T. Moses today called attention to the general election to be held in Virginia on Tuesday, November 6 . He cited the fact that county officers are to be elected on that date, and urged that there be a large turn-out of voters. There are some 2,200 eligible voters in the county, and the Appomattox tradition is for a heavy vote.

Thin class will be given by practicing In terior Decorators who are member of the Virginia Chapter, American Institute of Desijn, under the direc tion ef the University of Virginia Extension, and sponsored by the Womans Club of Appomattox. The first class, with John Manzer lecturing on Fun, Facts and Falla cies in Decorating, will meet at the Appomattox High School, Room IT Tuesday, Oct. 29, at 7 P. M. document.text: School Chorus, under the direction of M s. Teresa Quesenberry, w ill provide musical entertainment during the ceremonies after the parade. A new attraction to this years Railroad Festival will be an Air Show, Sunday, Septem ber 24 from 4 p.m. until dusk, weather permitting. Sky is the Limit from Lynchburg will have their hot air balloon and hangglider. Richmond Gra phics will also have a hot air balloon. Dave Carnes and Je ff Schultz will have hanggliders and there w ill also be exhibitions by tow kites, parachutists and parasails. All this can be seen at the home of James R. Ford, Jr ., Locust Grove Farm, 1 mile from 460 on the Church Street Extension. Highway 641. Arrangements for the Air Show were made by Mr. Bill Britton, Town Manager and Assistant to the Board of Supervisors. The Appomattox Womans Club is hosting the M iss Appomattox Beauty Pageant Saturday night, 800 at the high school. Sunday at 1230 p.m ., the former Virginia Governor Mills Godwin will unveil a portrait of the late Virginia Senator Charles T . Moses, given by his fam ily to the County of Appomattox. Virginia Fibre Corp. and the Future Farmers of America are providing i  crosscut sawing contest on Saturday and Sunday. The Beard Growing Contest, sponsored by the Downtown Merchants Association, will be judged at 230 Saturday afternoon. The entrants are requested to report to toe contest area at that time. The prizes will be awarded at 3 p.m. in the Depot area. An historic dress contest is scheduled for Sunday. Prises will be given in the five categories of men, women, children, couple, and family. Entrants should report to toe contest area at 180 and the winners will be announced at 315. Parking for toe handicapped will be at Coleman and Sons on Main Street. Main, Harold and Lee Streets will be dosed to traffic. Limited parking will be available surrounding toe down town area. We suggest parking at Appomattox County High School. Shuttle buses will be running between downtown and ACHS every 15 minutes for an hour at the beginning and end of each day. A com plete schedule of events and bus times can be found in the Depot Journal - the newspaper publiihed by the festival. Although the Appomattox Junior Womans Club and the Town of Appom attox are co-sponsoring the Festival, many civic organizations and local businesses have partici pated in the planning and production of the Sixth Annual Railroad Festival, September 28 and 24.

document.text: ner. In reviewing the history of the bank since its organization in 1918, Mr. Abbitt stated that the primary purpose then was not to make money but to serve as a community project. Mr. Abbitt told the stockholders it was an institution to be proud of and cited figures of dividends paid in past years. F. L. Murphy, president, in ad dressing the group, thanked the stockholders for their past co-opera tion and expressed his gratitude for, the confidence implied in his election to this office in 1937 and re-election each year since. George F. Abbitt Jr., was named to preside as chairman over the busi ness session. Of the 500 shares of stock there were 393 represented, 266 in person and 127 by proxy. T. DeWitt Evans, cashier, was called upon to read minutes of last years meeting which were approved. Mr. Evans then gave the financial statement which revealed from the set income 6,000.00 was divided among the stockholders. He gave ia- teresting facts of the banks growth with resources four times the amount reported 10 years ago and deposits more than four times as great in the same length of time. Unanimously re-elected were the twelve directors, George F. Abbitt Jr., W. M. Abbitt, Charles F. P. Crawley, T. DeWitt Evans, C. S. Jenkins, C. S. Me Dear-man, L. J. Morris, Wiley M. Morris, C. T. Moses, T. W. Moses, F. L. Murphy asd Mrs. Mary B. Murphy. Two new directors were elected, Alfred- R. Harwood Jr., and Charles T. Moses Jr. After the directors took the oath of office, the present officers of the bank were re-elected F. L. Murphy, president Luther J. Morris, vice- president. C. S. McDearmon, vice- president T. DeWitt Evass, cashier and Mrs. Jessalyn Drinkard, assist ant cashiei. The past presidents of the bank in the order which they served were, C. W. Hancock, C. A. Hancock, M. C. Smith and F. L. Murphy. A silent pause was observed in memory of the late C. A. Hancock and Alfred R. Harwood Sr., a past I president and a past cashier of the bank, respectively, who have passed on Bince the last meeting.

document.text: NAMED TO DEANS LIST LEXINGTON - Feb. 7 - At I Virginia Military Institute 300 cadets have been named to the deans list for the first semester of the academic year. The honor list, which requires a grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale, is almost evenly divided between Vir ginia and out-of-state cadets, with the largest number coming from the senior and junior classes. Among those named is Charles T. Moses, III, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. T. Moses, Jr., of Appomattox. Moses is a history major in his third year atVMI.

document.text: Mrs. Eula F. Wooldridge Mrs. Eula Fleshman Woold ridge, 85, who had rriade her home for the past 25 years with her son and daughter - in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Jeter Witt Woold ridge at 229 Chestnut St., Cov ington, died at 715 p.m., Thurs day, Feb. 28, in the CO Hos pital, Clifton Forge, where she had undergone emergency sur gery, Feb. 21. Mrs. Wooldridge was born in Appomattox County, March 24, 1878, a daughter of the late Willis Fleshman and Bertie Whitehead Fleshman. She was a member of the Concord Presbyterian Church in Charlotte County. Surviving other than her son, is one brother, E. W. Fleshman, of Roanoke and Wytheville. She was preceded in death by her husband, Jeter Cury Wooldridge, in 1933, and by one son Joel Thomas Woolridge, in 1910. A funeral service was held Sun day at 2 p.m. in the Concord Presbyterian Church, with her pastor, the Rev. Mr. Skidmore officiating. Interment was in the church cemetery. Active pallbearers were W. A. Haynes, Fred Martin, DeWutt Harvey, Frank Fleshmlan, Clyde Fleshman, Wlalter Smith, Law rence Stewart, Jr., and Duval Conner. Honorary pallbearers were Courtney Harvey, George Threa- ves, Dr. UMty Monger Powell, Dr. Wlalter Johnson, Dr. M. I. Hanna, Mrs. Carolyn Dykes Dr. Meade Edmunds, Dr. J. M. Em mett, Dr. R. Preston Hawkins, Richard F. Beime m , Earl Key. T. I. Hardy, Howard Davis, J. B. Vaughan, Robert MteCaleb, the Rev. Ryburn T. Siancil, Tom Christian, Ernest Schumaker, Senator Bale Collins, Senator Charles T. Moses, and Congress man Watkins Abbitt. Also, the Hunter family of Charlotte Coun ty nephews, great- nephews, husbands of her Meces and the Women of the Concord Presby terian Church.

document.text: Mrs. Charles T. Moses, Jr. of Appomattox was elected presi dent of South Central District, Virginia Federation of Garden Clubs, Inc., at its annual meeting in Farmville on Tues., April 8. Mrs. Moses, a member of the Appomattox Garden Club since 1947, has served two terms as its president. She has also served the District as Director - Treasurer as well es many committee chairmanships. She is a National Council Accredited Flower Show Judge holding a Masters Certificate and wUl complete her two year term as President of South Central District Council of Nationally Accredited Flower Show Judges in May. She is also a member of The Virginia Council of Nationally Accredit ed Flower Show Judges. For six years she has served on the Board of Directors of the Virginia Federation of Garden Clubs, Inc. and is currently serving as Memorial Gardens Chairman for the State. Mrs. Moses has chosen as the theme for the next two years - Conservation Today - Our Heritage for Tomorrow The Horticulture project will be Daffodils  a new one in every garden. The objectives 1. To con tinue to support state and national objectives. 2. Involve ment - of every member. I suppose I inherited the love of flowers and gardening from my mother but I didnt inherit her green thumb, she says. With my church my family and my Garden Club work, I hardly find time to garden. document.text: Mr. and Mrs, William Robertson Herndon, Jr., of Brookneal, announce the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Virginia, to Timothy Wayne Gentry, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wingate Gentry of Booneville, North Carolina. Miss Herndon is the granddaughter of the late Senator and Mrs. Charles T. Moses, Sr. of Appomattox. She is a graduate of William Campbell High School and Averett College and is presently employed by the Campbell County School System. Mr. Gentry is a graduate of George Washington High School and attended Danville Community College. He is employed by Yeargin Construction Company in Winston-Salem. . The wedding will take place June 3 at Charmos, paternal ancestral home, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Webster Babcock, aunt and uncle of the bride.

document.text: Mr. and Mrs. Walter William Puckette of Gladys announce the engagement of their daughter. Merle Scott to William Robertson Herndon, III, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Herndon, Jr. of Brookneal. Miss Puckette is a graduate of William Campbell High School and received a B.S. degree in education, with a specialization in reading from Averett College in Dnville, Virginia. She is presently working toward a masters degree in education from Lynchburg College. The bride-elect te presently employed with Lynchburg Public Schools. Mr. Herndon is a graduate of William Campbell High School and received a B.A. degree from Lynchburg College. He is presently employed with Campbell County Schools System. Mr. Herndon is the grandson of the late Senator and Mrs. Charles T. Moses. The wedding date is set for June 19.
